questions.text: Which of the following tests is done before performing an A-V fistula procedure? The image of the test is given below.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Allen test

Highyeild:

Allen’s test is performed before radial artery cannulation to determine whether ulnar collateral circulation to the hand is adequate in case of radial artery thrombosis. The hand is exsanguinated by having the patient make a tight fist. The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded by manual compression, the patient relaxes the hand, and the pressure over the ulnar artery is released. Collateral flow is assessed by measuring the time required for return of normal coloration. Return of color in less than 5 seconds indicates adequate collateral flow, return in 5 to 10 seconds suggests an equivocal test, and return in more than 10 seconds indicates inadequate collateral circulation

Random:

Explanation for other options: - B.WRIGHT TEST Wright test or hyperabduction test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is thought to implicate the axillary interval Step one: The therapist places the patient’s shoulder into abduction and external rotation to 90 degrees. The elbow is flexed to no more than 45 degrees. This position is held for 1 minute. Step two: Repeat the previous test with the patient’s arm in hyperabduction (end range of abduction). Positive test: change in radial pulse and/or symptom reproduction Option C. Adson’s test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome Accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles Option D. ROOS TEST This test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS). It is also known as the “elevated arm stress test” or “EAST

questions.text: A 35 year old male met with an RTA and was brought to the Emergency room with Shaft of Femur fracture. The patient was stabilized but after 12 hours he developed a sudden onset breathlessness, confusion and petechial rash over the chest. THE Probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fat embolism syndrome Fat embolism occurs when fat globules enter the bloodstream,usually as a result of trauma such as long bone fracture. In this case, the patient had a femur fracture due to a road traffic accident.

Highyeild:

Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is a medical condition characterized by the presence of fat globules in the bloodstream that can obstruct blood vessels and cause tissue damage. This condition typically occurs after a traumatic injury, such as a long bone fracture or major orthopedic surgery. It’s most commonly associated with fractures of the long bones, like the femur or tibia, as well as pelvic fractures and other severe traumatic injuries. The organs most commonly affected by fat embolism syndrome include the lungs, brain, and skin. Symptoms of fat embolism syndrome can vary and may include: Respiratory symptoms: Shortness of breath, rapid breathing, and low oxygen levels in the blood can occur due to fat globules obstructing blood vessels in the lungs. Neurological symptoms: Confusion, altered mental status, and even seizures can result from fat emboli reaching the brain and causing damage to brain tissue. Skin symptoms: Petechiae, which are small red or purple spots on the skin caused by bleeding under the skin, can develop. These typically appear on the chest, upper arms, and neck. Other symptoms: Fever, rapid heart rate, and low blood pressure may also be present. Diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome is primarily clinical, based on a combination of symptoms and the patient’s history of trauma or surgery. Imaging studies, such as chest X-rays and brain scans, may help confirm the presence of fat emboli and assess the extent of organ involvement. Treatment of fat embolism syndrome involves supportive measures to manage the symptoms and improve oxygenation and blood flow. This may include supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilation, fluid resuscitation, and medications to support heart function. In severe cases, patients may require intensive care and close monitoring. Prevention is a key aspect of managing fat embolism syndrome. Proper immobilization of fractures, especially long bone fractures, and careful surgical techniques can help minimize the risk of fat emboli entering the bloodstream.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Hemorrhagic shock would have given a history of bleeding or even if its innocuous it would have shown a fall in BP, tachycardia, altered mental state, cold clammy extremities Option: C. Any patient with chest trauma should be investigated for Open pneumothorax, Tension pneumothorax, Pericardial tamponade, Flail chest, Massive hemothorax and airway obstruction. Trauma to chest would cause any of these and they present with acute findings in the emergency. Option: D. Hypovolemic shock is due to loss of intravascular fluid, leading to fall in BP, Tachycardia and cold clammy skin and extremities

questions.text: A 14 years old male presented with a mushroomlike tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features will help the clinician to identify a malignant transformation?

options.label: A
options.text: On X-ray and CT there is a connection between bone and lesion, then the lesion is malignant

options.label: B
options.text: Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm .

options.label: C
options.text: If bone lesion is growing towards joint the lesion is malignant

options.label: D
options.text: Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm .
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm . The given x-ray shows a well defined exostosis pointing to the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 2 cm thickness of hyaline cap thickness on MRI suggestive of malignant transformation.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B: Bone marrow is continuous with parent bone: This is a fundamental characteristic of an osteochondroma along with presence of a cartilaginous cap. It does not suggest malignant transformation. Hence it is incorrect. Option C: The cartilaginous growth towards the joint: This option is incorrect. Osteochondroma typically grows away from the growth plate. I.e away from the joint. This feature is not related to malignant transformation of an osteochondroma. Option D: Cartilage thickness > 3 cm : This option is incorrect because the cut off criteria for malignant transformation of osteochondroma is > 2 mm.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial epicondyle The given clinical situation with a positive card test and an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits, suggest an ulnar nerve injury. The site injured is medial epicondyle.

Highyeild:

Injury at the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve,leading to paralysis of flexor carpi ulnaris leads to loss of ulnar deviation,and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus leads to loss of DIPjoint flexion. It leads of hypothenar paralysis leads to atrophy and sensory loss The card test for Froment’s sign is a clinical test that can be easily performed for assessment of ulnar nerve, it is due to weakness of the palmar interossei leading to loss of adduction. Branch of ulnar nerve includes: Muscular branch: Controls movement in the front of the forearm. Dorsal cutaneous branch: Sends sensory information between the brain and the middle back of the hand, pinky finger and ring finger. Palmar cutaneous branch: Sends sensory information to and from the middle part of the palm and pinky and ring fingers. Superficial branch: Supplies and passes under the Palmaris brevis muscles and divides into palmar digita l nerves Deep branch: Innervates the three hypothenar muscles, the two medial lumbricals, the seven interrosei, the adductor pollicis and the deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis. Test for ulnar nerve lesion: Claw hand deformity Froment sign positive Wartenberg sign Palmaris brevis sign

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Radial groove - radial nerve Option B. Neck of humerus- axillary nerve Option C. L ateral epicondyle -may lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy after fracture but the incidence is less

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident with a suspected pelvic fracture. On examination, he is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the earliest treatment for the control of hemorrhage in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Tying a bed sheet around pelvis and trochanter

questions.correct_answer: C. Tying a bed sheet around pelvis and trochanter
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tying a bed sheet around pelvis and trochanter If a person has a pelvic injury and you’re unable to access medical assistance quickly, you can consider improvising a makeshift pelvic binder using a bed sheet as a temporary measure.

Highyeild:

Management of pelvic fracture: Initial Assessment and Stabilization: Assess the patient’s overall condition, including airway, breathing, circulation, and neurological status. Stabilize any life-threatening injuries before addressing the pelvic fracture. Immobilize the patient using a backboard and cervical spine precautions if spinal injury is suspected. Hemodynamic Stability: Unstable pelvic fractures can result in significant bleeding due to damage to blood vessels and surrounding tissues. Maintain hemodynamic stability through fluid resuscitation and blood transfusions as needed. Pain Management: Pelvic fractures can be extremely painful. Adequate pain control is essential for patient comfort and cooperation. Imaging and Assessment: Perform imaging studies, such as X-rays, CT scans, or ultrasound, to determine the type and extent of the pelvic fracture. Stable Fractures: Stable fractures with minimal displacement may be managed conservatively with pain control, limited weight-bearing, and early mobilization with the help of physical therapy. Unstable Fractures: Unstable fractures with significant displacement or associated ligamentous injuries require more aggressive management. External fixation or pelvic binder may be used to stabilize the pelvis and control bleeding before surgical intervention. Surgical Intervention: Some unstable pelvic fractures may require surgical fixation to stabilize the pelvic ring and reduce the risk of further displacement. Internal fixation techniques, such as plates, screws, and rods, may be used to restore stability. Complications Prevention: Patients with pelvic fractures are at risk of complications such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, pressure sores, and pneumonia. Preventive measures include early mobility, prophylactic anticoagulation, and proper positioning. Monitoring and Rehabilitation: Continuously monitor the patient’s condition, especially if they have associated injuries or underlying health conditions. Initiate rehabilitation, including physical therapy, to restore mobility and function once the fracture begins to heal. Multidisciplinary Care: Pelvic fractures often require coordination among various specialists, including orthopedic surgeons, trauma surgeons, radiologists, anesthesiologists, and rehabilitation professionals.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: External fixation:This step comes after application of pelvic binder. Hence this option is incorrect. Option B: Internal definite fixation : Definite internal fixation is done only after the patient has been stabilized and is fit for surgery. Steps like blood transfusion,pelvic binder and external fixation take precedence . Hence incorrect option. Option D: Pelvic binder comes before blood transfusion . Applying a pelvic binder helps in controlling the internal bleeding first then there is provision for rapid blood transfusion.
